abstract.p: This study explores the behavior of textile fabrics under thermal exposures. The performance of thermal protective textile fabric systems with different structural features was evaluated under laboratory simulated thermal exposures. The study demonstrated that the protective performance of textile fabric systems varies with different types of thermal exposure. To provide effective protection in flame and radiant-heat exposures, the most important fabric properties to address are emissivity, absorptivity and thermal resistance. In hot surface exposures, the compression property of the fabric systems is the primary feature to consider for protection. Hot water and steam exposures produce mass transfer through fabrics. In the presence of water or steam jet pressure, fabric compression is a primary factor in protecting the human body. The findings obtained in this study can be used to engineer fabric systems that provide better protection from various thermal exposures.

body.p: According to the United States Fire Administration Statistics, every year nearly 75,000 to 85,000 firefighters are injured while fighting fires, rescuing people, and responding to hazardous material incidents.1 Industrial workers are subjected to workplace injuries due to electrical flashes, slag burns, gaseous burns, flame burns, scalds, and chemical burns. While the majority of such injuries are minor, a significant number are debilitating and career-ending. Protective clothing is the only barrier between these workers and the skin burns that can result from thermal hazards; thus, the performance of this clothing must be constantly updated by implementing new fabric systems that have been evaluated in the laboratory.2–4

The performance of protective clothing varies with the type of exposure, the structural features of the clothing, and the characteristics of the fabric.2–9 Loose-fitting clothing with controlled fullness and appropriate closures provided better thermal protection than close-fitting clothing when flash fire experiments were performed on a manikin.2 Loose-fitting clothing has more air gaps than close-fitting clothing and the air gaps improve the thermal protection. The style, size, fit, ease, and drape of garments together with attributes such as cuffs, pockets, and closures affect the number of air layers between the wearer’s body and the garment, improving the thermal protective performance of the clothing in flame exposures.3–5 The impact of clothing features on thermal protective performance in flame exposure using the PyroMan flash fire manikin evaluation system was also investigated.6 It has been shown that if the number of air gaps inside the clothing structure is high, the body is better insulated and the clothing provides better thermal protection in flame exposure.

Heat and mass transfer to a wearer’s body can be improved by careful selection of textile fabric. Textile fabric is generally a porous media that comprises two phases—solid (consisting of solid fibers) and gas (consisting of water vapor and dry air).10,11 The compression property of the fabric plays an important role when thermal energy is transferred through a person’s clothing to the person’s body through physical contact with a hot object.12–14 Significant compression mainly reduces the amount of the gaseous phase inside the fabric structure, which in turn lowers the thermal insulation of the fabric. As a result, the thermal protective performance reduces. The heat transfer in flame and radiant-heat exposures is controlled mainly by the gas and vapor phases in the fabric structure.11

In the early 1980s, Benisek and Phillips7 analyzed the thermal protective performance of single layered and double layered fabrics in high intensity flame exposures. They found that the thickness and weight of fabrics affected their protective performance, and that the protection of double layered fabrics was much higher than that of single layered fabrics. The thermal protective performance of single layered fabrics was affected by changes in the intensity of thermal exposure and by the thickness and weight of the fabric.8,15

In a combined exposure of flame and radiant-heat that resembled an actual fire hazard scenario, the thermal energy transmitted through fabric could cause skin burn injuries, especially in radiant-heat exposure.16 The thermal energy transfer rate was lower in thick fabrics than in thin fabrics and air permeability did not significantly affect the transfer of thermal energy. The air permeability has little or no impact on thermal protective performance.

The fabric weight and thickness are the main properties to consider while analyzing fabric performance in low intensity radiant-heat exposures. Through statistical analysis, it has been confirmed that fabric weight and thickness are positively associated with thermal protective performance.17 Fabrics with a high weight and thickness entrap more dead air than thinner fabrics, and this air could help to insulate the wearer.18 However, the thick fabrics store more energy than thin fabrics in low intensity radiant-heat exposures, and this stored energy is released due to a better contact between fabric and human skin during and after the exposure.9 This released energy causes a quick burn injury on the wearer’s skin and consequently lowers the performance of the thermal protective clothing.19 The textile fabrics absorb moisture due to perspiration from a sweating firefighter; this absorbed moisture increases the thermal conductivity and heat capacity of textile fibers, lowering the thermal protective performance of the fabric.19,20 In contrast, it was also notable that if a fabric absorbs a significantly high amount of water (more than 15% of its weight), this situation ultimately provides a cooling effect to the firefighters by reducing the thermal energy transfer.18

If moisture that has accumulated inside the fabric structure turns to steam during a thermal exposure, the steam could diffuse toward the skin depending upon fabric characteristics, leading to skin burn.21–25 Similarly, water used by firefighters to extinguish flames may generate steam in the environment and thus be transferred through a firefighter’s clothing to produce skin burn. The water vapor permeability is the most important fabric property to consider for effective protection in steam exposures.21 An impermeable membrane inside the fabric layers might significantly prevent steam transfer and reduce the burn injuries of the wearers. A thick fabric with an impermeable membrane provides better protection from steam than a thick fabric with a semi-permeable membrane.22,23

Ackerman et al.26 characterized high performance textile fabric systems in hot liquid (water, water based drilling mud, canola oil) exposures at 85℃. The drilling mud (manufactured by SAGDRIL) and canola oil were mainly used to simulate industrial and kitchen hazards, respectively. It was observed that both the density and heat capacity of water at 85℃ were the highest among all liquids, whereas the viscosity of water at 85℃ was the lowest. It has been found that the protective performance of the textile fabric systems depended on fabric properties (e.g., weight, thickness, air permeability, finishing) and the heat capacities of the liquids. It has also been found that air permeability of a fabric system was negatively associated with protective performance and that fabrics with encapsulated fiber finishing provided the best protection against all types of hot liquid. Fabric performance was the lowest for hot water; this was thought to be mainly because the heat capacity of hot water is higher than the heat capacity of drilling mud and canola oil.

Based on the above discussion, a great deal of research made considerable efforts to characterize thermal protective fabrics under specific thermal exposures. However, few or hardly any researcher studied the characteristics of fabrics or fabric systems under all types of thermal exposures. In this study, based on Mandal and Song’s recent study,27 the behavior of textile fabrics under thermal exposures was explored and characterized. The performance of thermal protective textile fabric systems with different structural features was evaluated under laboratory simulated thermal exposures.

sec.title: Fabric selection
sec.p:
In manufactured thermal protective clothing, three layered fabric systems are generally used—an outer shell, a moisture barrier, and a thermal liner. In this study, high performance fabrics were selected for the three layers based on fiber content, weave structure, and thickness, as shown in Table 1. The fabrics employed are commercially available and commonly used in the manufacturing of thermal protective clothing. By assembling these fabrics, various fabric systems (single layered, double layered, and three layered) were developed and their physical properties were measured according to American Society for Testing and Material (ASTM) standards (Table 2). sec.title: Test conditions and approaches
sec.p: The protective performances of the selected single layered, double layered, and three layered fabric systems (Table 2) were tested by bench-scale tests. For testing in dry condition, fabric systems were preconditioned for 24 hours at 21 ± 1℃, 65 ± 2% relative humidity. Then fabric systems were subjected to thermal exposures long enough for the time required to generate a second degree burn on human skin to be calculated. Three samples of each fabric system were tested. The mean deviation of calculated burn time was maintained within the limits of ± 2.5%.

During thermal exposure, the energy transmitted through the fabric system was measured every 0.1 seconds by a skin simulant sensor. The modified ASTM F 1930-00 (standard test method for the evaluation of flame resistant clothing for protection against flash fire simulations using an instrumented manikin) standard method was followed to predict the second degree burn injury. In this process, the skin simulant sensor worked according to the skin model. The thermal energy transmission within the sensor was represented as a transient, one dimensional heat diffusion problem in which the temperature within the human skin (epidermis layer) and under the human skin (dermis, subcutaneous layers) varies with skin depth and exposure time. Using this skin model, the skin burn injury was calculated based on Henrique’s burn integral equation.

sec.title: Flame exposures
sec.p:
Protective performance in flame exposure was measured using the modified ISO 9151 testing approach shown in Figure 1. The flame was delivered from a Meker propane gas burner with a diameter of 38 mm (Figure 1(a)). The burner was adjusted to deliver a heat flux of 84 kW/m2. The fabric sample (10 cm × 10 cm) was mounted (Figure 1(b)) above the burner using the specimen support frame (Figure 1(c)) with the outer layer of the fabric system facing the burner. The fabric sample was protected from the heat source before and after the test run. At the time of the test, the burner was placed under the fabric sample and the flame was delivered for a time that depended on the fabric system. The thermal energy transferred through the fabric sample was measured using a skin simulant sensor (Figure 1(d)) mounted on an insulation board (Figure 1(e)) and located behind the fabric sample. The heat flux history measured by the skin simulant sensor (Figure 1(f)) was recorded and the second degree burn time was calculated by the software program (Figure 1(g)). Figure 1.
Schematic diagram of the flame exposure test.

sec.title: Radiant-heat exposures
sec.p:
To measure fabric protective performance in radiant-heat exposure, the cone calorimeter (Figure 2) test was conducted with a modified ASTM E 1354 testing approach. Heat was generated by a truncated cone-shaped electrically heated (5000 W, 240 V) coil (Figure 2 (a)) adjusted to deliver a heat flux of 50 kW/m2. The sample fabric system (15 cm × 15 cm) was horizontally mounted (Figure 2 (b)) below the heated coil. The heat flux was uniform within the central 50 mm × 50 mm area of the sample. A transverse shutter was used to protect the fabric sample from the heat source before and after the test. The radiant-heat exposure time for different fabric systems was varied according to the fabric system structure. A skin simulant sensor (Figure 2 (c)) located behind the test sample measured the thermal energy transferred through the fabric system during the heat exposure. The sensor value was recorded and the second degree skin burn time was calculated with the software program (Figure 2 (d)). Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of the radiant-heat exposure test.

sec.title: Hot surface exposures
sec.p:
The fabric protective performance in hot surface exposures was measured according to the modified ASTM F 1060 (Figure 3) method. The fabric system sample (10 cm × 15 cm) was horizontally placed (Figure 3 (a)) on a hot surface plate of electrolytic copper (Figure 3 (b)) under a load of 1 kg (Figure 3 (d)). The temperature of the hot surface (Figure 3 (c)) was controlled at 400℃ with a thermocouple and heat transmitted by the test specimen was measured through a skin simulant sensor (Figure 3 (e)) mounted above the fabric sample in an insulated board. Depending on the fabric structure, the exposure time was set to generate a second degree skin burn. The skin simulant sensor measured the heat flux history and the heat fluxes were used to calculate the time requirements for a second degree skin burn injury using the software program (Figure 3f). Figure 3.
Schematic diagram of the hot surface exposure test.

sec.title: Hot water exposures
sec.p:
The hot water exposure test was conducted using a modified ASTM F 2701 (Figure 4) method. The fabric system sample was mounted on an inclined (45°) sensor board (Figure 4 (a)) made of nonconductive, liquid and heat resistant material. The sensor board had two skin simulant sensors—an upper sensor (Figure 4 (b1)) representing a direct exposure point of the fabric system to the hot water, and a lower sensor (Figure 4 (b2)) representing an off-direct exposure point of the fabric system to the hot water. Hot water was prepared in a circulating bath (Figure 4 (c)) and its temperature was maintained at 85℃ using a temperature control device (Figure 4 (d)). The hot water was circulated through a circulation valve (Figure 4 (f)) attached with a flow controlled valve (Figure 4 (e)). This circulation process helped to warm-up the water pipe in order to regulate the water temperature within the pipe at 85℃. Using a water tap (Figure 4 (g)), the hot water was passed through the water outlet (Figure 4 (h)). By employing a thermocouple at the front of the outlet, the water temperature was constantly monitored. It was observed that the temperature at the outlet reached closed to 85℃ within 0.5 seconds immediately after opening the water tap. Then, the fabric sample was continuously exposed to the hot water for a duration that was calculated to generate a second degree burn according to the fabric system being tested. The thermal energy (in the form of heat and mass transmitted through the fabric sample) at the direct exposure points was measured using skin simulant sensors (Figure 4 (b1) and (b2)). The obtained heat flux values were recorded and used to calculate the time requirements for a second degree skin burn injury using the programmed software (Figure 4 (i)). Figure 4.
Schematic diagram of the hot water exposure test.

sec.title: Steam exposures
sec.p:
A schematic diagram of the steam tester developed by the Protective Clothing and Equipment Research Facility (PCERF, Canada) laboratory research team is illustrated in Figure 5.27 Steam was generated through a 3 kW boiler (Figure 5 (a)) at a temperature of 150℃. The conditioned fabric test sample (200 mm × 200 mm) was placed on a Teflon plated sample holder (Figure 5 (b)) with an embedded skin simulant sensor (Figure 5 (c)). The initial temperature of the sensor was set at 25℃. The generated steam was impinged at a pressure of 200 kPa from 50 mm above the fabric sample through a nozzle having a diameter of 4.6 mm (Figure 5 (d)). The duration of the steam exposure was controlled according to the fabric system to generate a second degree burn through the software program. During and after the steam exposure, the heat flux through the fabric sample was measured using the skin simulant sensor. The time required to generate a second degree skin burn was calculated by the software program (Figure 5 (e)). Figure 5.
Schematic diagram of the steam exposure test.

sec.title: Procedure to analyze the experimental results
sec.p: The second degree skin burn times of the selected fabric systems in all thermal exposures were tabulated. For a particular exposure, fabric systems with higher protective performance required longer times to produce second degree skin burn injury.

Fabric system properties (thickness and air permeability) and protective performance (second degree burn time) were normalized between −1 to +1, with an average value set to zero. The normalized variable Xi,norm is represented by equation (1). The normalization process reduces the redundancy rates in the data by pulling out abnormal factors. (1)Xi,norm=Xi-Xi,avgRi,max where, Ri,max=Maximum[(Xi,max-Xi,avg),(Xi,avg-Xi,min)] .

In equation (1), Xi is the value of a selected variable (thickness, air permeability, or second degree burn time), Xi,avg is the average value of that particular variable, Xi,min is the minimum value of that variable, Xi,max is the maximum value of that variable, and Ri,max is the maximum range between the average value and either the minimum or the maximum of that variable. In order to understand the association between fabric system properties and protective performance, a t-test of a normalized dataset was conducted using StatCrunch software (developed by programmers and statisticians led by Webster West of Texas A&M University). The association was inferred based on the sign (+ or −) of the T-stat value obtained from the t-test. P-values obtained from the t-test for individual fabric properties were analyzed to identify fabric properties that significantly affected the second degree burn time. Significance tests were carried out at the significance level 0.05. Thus, if the obtained P-value for any considered aspect was less than 0.05, that aspect was inferred to be statistically significant. A relationship plot was developed between the second degree burn time and significant fabric properties, and the coefficient of determination (R2) of the developed plot was calculated. An R2 value with proximity to 1 inferred a strong association between the second degree burn time and the significant fabric property. Inference tests [hypothesis test (P-value) and confidence interval (upper and lower limits)] were carried out to understand the differences in second degree burn times of different fabric systems in various thermal exposures.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: During flame exposure, the flame was produced through the controlled combustion of flammable propane gas. The flame generates a jet of hot gaseous molecules that move toward the fabric surface. As the moving air mass imposes thermal energy on the fabric system, convection is the primary mode of heat transfer in flame exposure. As some thermal energy radiates from the flame surface toward the fabric, radiation is the secondary mode of heat transfer in flame exposure. In radiant-heat exposure, electromagnetic waves radiate from a conical electrical heat source toward the fabric system, imposing electromagnetic energy on the fabric system; therefore, radiation is the primary mode of heat transfer. Physical contact between the fabric system and a hot surface results in conduction being the primary mode of heat transfer in hot surface exposure. Convection (moving water molecules) is the primary modes of mass and heat transfer in steam and hot water exposures.

The protective performance of fabric systems varies under each type of thermal exposure. Flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures transferred mainly heat through the fabric system; whereas, mainly a mass transfer through water containing a large amount of thermal energy occurred in steam and hot water exposures. During mass transfer, liquid and vaporized water molecules diffuse along their concentration gradients. As the steam exposures occur with a high pressure, it is expected that vaporized water molecules will have a greater momentum than liquid water molecules present in hot water exposures. In turn, the mass transfer rate is greater during steam exposures than during hot water exposures.

sec.p:
The protective performance (second degree burn time) of the selected fabric systems (A–FAD) obtained through laboratory-simulated flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures are presented in Table 3. Second degree burn times of three layered fabric systems are mostly higher than second degree burn times of single and double layered fabric systems, inferring that three layered fabric systems provide more protection than single and double layered fabric systems to a wearer exposed to a flame, radiant-heat, or hot surface exposure. As shown in Table 4, T-stat values for fabric air permeability in flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures are negative, whereas, T-stat values for fabric thickness are positive in the same exposures. Negative T-stat values indicate a negative association between air permeability and second degree burn time. The association between fabric thickness and second degree burn time is positive in flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures. P-values of fabric air permeability in flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures are 0.42, 0.45, and 0.19, respectively. As all fabric air permeability P-values are greater than 0.05, it can be inferred that fabric air permeability is not a significant factor in second degree burn time. The negative downplay of fabric air permeability in these exposures indicates that thermal energy should necessarily blow through the fabric systems. It has been hypothesized that thermal energy transfer mechanisms through multiphase, non-homogeneous fabric systems entail a combination of absorption, re-radiation/reflection, conduction, and possibly forced convection.10,11,16

P-values of fabric thickness under flame and radiant-heat exposure are 0.002 and 0.001, respectively. The P-values indicate that thickness is a highly significant fabric property for effective protection under flame and radiant-heat exposures. The values in Table 4 also suggest that fabric thickness is not a highly significant property to protect a wearer from burn injury in a hot surface exposure [(P-value)hot surface = 0.07, >0.05]. Heat transfer in hot surface exposures proceeds through a pressure or load on the fabric system that is not present in flame and radiant-heat exposures. Consequently, the thermal energy transfer mechanism through the fabric systems in hot surface exposures differs from those in both the flame and radiant-heat exposures. Relationships between fabric thickness and second degree burn time in flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposures are shown in Figure 6 to individually explain and compare the exposures in detail. Figure 6.
Relationship between fabric thickness and second degree burn time in flame, radiant-heat, and hot surface exposure.

Figure 6 confirms the T-stat values that showed a positive association between fabric thickness and second degree burn time. In comparison between flame and radiant-heat exposures, it is clear that the coefficient of determination (R2) between fabric thickness and second degree burn time is different. This infers that there is a different level of association between fabric thickness and second degree burn time in the case of flame and radiant-heat exposures. In flame and radiant-heat exposures, thermal energy is imposed on the multiphase (solid and gaseous) fabric systems and the incident thermal energy may be partially reflected, and/or absorbed, and/or transmitted depending on the fabric system’s emissivity or absorbtivity.16,28 The emissivity (ɛ) of a fabric system is strongly dependent upon the nature of its surface optical properties. The surface optical properties are basically influenced by the method of fabrication, finishing, temperature/thermal cycling and chemical reactions during thermal exposures. A fabric system with maximum emissivity (ɛ ∼ 1) reflects less thermal energy than a fabric system with minimum emissivity (ɛ ∼ 0); therefore, thermal energy imposed on fabrics with high emissivity is mostly absorbed inside the fabric system and/or transmitted to the skin. In this study, mainly Kevlar/PBI and Nomex fabric were used. According to Song’s study, the emissivity of these fabrics is nearly 0.9; in turn, these fabrics have a significant contribution to absorb and/or transmit thermal energy toward human skin.28

The thermal energy transmitted through a fabric system comes into direct contact with the skin and may generate burn injury. Also, thermal energy absorbed inside the fabric system can move toward the wearer’s skin and generate burn injury. Normally, thick fabric systems provide higher protection against thermal hazards because they contain more trapped air than thin fabric systems. The trapped air volumes act as an insulator, lowering the transmissivity of the fabric system, and hence reducing the penetration rate of thermal energy from the fabric system to the skin. Adding a moisture barrier and a thermal liner to a fabric shell will substantially increase wearers’ protection by increasing the amount of air phase and trapped air volume.

Although a three layered fabric system might contain more air between the layers than a single layered fabric contains in its pores, the insulating effect of the additional air space might be compromised by the increase in thermal energy that can be stored inside the fabric layers. This stored energy might be transmitted to the wearer’s skin over time. This energy would transmit regardless of whether the fabric is compressed or not. As fabrics usually compress when the wearer moves this compression may reduce the thermal protective performance of the fabric system.9,18

Interestingly, that the coefficient of determination (R2) in flame and radiant-heat exposures were 0.8386 and 0.972, respectively (Figure 6) infers that fabric thickness may be strongly related to thermal protective performance (second degree burn time) in radiant-heat exposure compared to flame exposure. This is because in radiant-heat exposure thermal energy is mostly transmitted through the fabric system,29 while in flame exposure thermal energy imposed on the surface of the fabric system mainly spreads horizontally and/or bounces back to the environment depending upon the configuration of the exposure. Therefore, fabric thickness plays a more significant role in heat transmission to the wearer in radiant-heat exposure than in flame exposure.

Furthermore, it has been identified from the Figure 6 that the coefficient of determination (R2) in the hot surface exposure is much lower than those in flame and radiant-heat exposures. At a particular thickness, the second degree burn time in hot surface exposures is also much lower than those of flame and radiant-heat exposures. To explain these phenomena, it is necessary to understand the behavior of thermal energy imposed on a fabric system in a hot surface exposure (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Behavior of thermal energy imposed on a fabric system ((a) = absorbed thermal energy, (b) = transmitted thermal energy) in a hot surface exposure.

Figure 7 shows that there is a physical contact between the hot surface and the fabric system in a hot surface exposure. The contact resistance between the fabric system and the hot surface may vary depending on the surface roughness of the fabric system (Figure 8). A fabric system with a rough surface (i.e. with high contact resistance or a high static frictional coefficient) will have a tiny air gap on the interface between the fabric system and the hot surface that reduces the thermal energy transfer inside the fabric system. A smooth fabric system surface (i.e. with a low contact resistance or a low static frictional coefficient) allows good thermal contact between the hot surface and the fabric system, increasing the thermal energy transfer inside the fabric system. Figure 8.
Thermal energy transfer through the interface between hot surface/fabric systems interfaces.

Compression of the fabric system decreases the air volumes in the fabric. Absence of an air phase inside a compressed fabric system (between the wearer’s skin and a hot surface) lowers the insulation of the fabric system; hence, the protective performance is decreased. When the solid fibre phase inside the fabric system predominates, the thermal conductivity is enhanced and the extinction coefficient of the fabric system becomes high. Thermo-physical properties (density, volumetric heat capacity) of the fabric system may also deteriorate depending on the compression in the fabric system.8 The rapid transmission of thermal energy through a compressed fabric system generates a quick burn on the wearer’s skin. Contact resistance between the fabric system and the wearer’s skin is also reduced with fabric compression, and this situation aggravates the thermal energy transmission toward the skin.

Fabric systems AFD and FAD have the same thickness, but the protective performance of AFD is almost twice that of FAD (Table 3). This is because in the FAD fabric system, the moisture barrier is present in the outer layer, whereas in the AFD fabric system the moisture barrier is present in the inner layer. The moisture barrier in the FAD fabric system comes into direct contact with the hot surface. The moisture barrier contains polyurethane coatings that may catch fire to melt easily (ignition temperature ∼ 370℃).30 Melting or ignition of the moisture barrier does not maintain the integrity of the fabric system, which enhances the transfers of thermal energy toward the skin, reducing the time requirement to generate a second degree burn. A molten surface of moisture barrier also reduces the contact resistance between hot surface and fabric system and, in turn, causes the poor protective performance of a fabric system. These phenomena are less profound for an AFD fabric system as the outer layer in these fabric systems comprises a specialized Kevlar-PBI fabric that has a high ignition temperature (∼600℃) and greater surface roughness; consequently, the integrity of the fabric system is maintained and it efficiently slows heat flow toward the skin. The findings for fabric systems AF and FA can be similarly compared; these fabric systems have similar thickness and air permeability but the burn time is higher (protection higher) for AF than for FA (Table 3) due to the position of the moisture barrier, which is in the inner layer of AF and in the outer layer of FA.

P-values for thickness and air permeability were less than 0.05 (Table 6) and thus both thickness and air permeability significantly affect fabric protective performance in hot water and steam exposures. The findings in this paper show that fabric thickness plays a significant role in heat transfer under hot water and steam exposures. Fabric air permeability is pertinent if mass transfer (hot liquid) results in skin burn;23,24 thus, in hot water and steam exposures air permeability of the fabric system is expected to be a significant property. In Table 6, the T-stat values for thickness and air permeability are positive and negative, respectively, indicating that thickness and permeability have positive and negative relationships, respectively, with second degree burn time. As thick fabric systems provide more insulation than thin fabric systems,9,11 heat transfer is less and second degree burn time is higher in thick fabric systems than in thin fabric systems. However, the presence of air pores in a highly air permeable fabric system may enhance the transfer of mass and reduce the time requirement for a second degree burn. For example, although the AE fabric system is thicker than the B fabric system, the second degree burn time of the AE fabric system is less than that of the B fabric system. A possible reason for this difference in second degree burn times might be that the air permeability of the AE fabric system is higher than the air permeability of the B fabric system. Here, it can be hypothesized that, although thickness and air permeability both have significant effects on protective performance, one property may dominate the other. To analyze this hypothesis, the P-values of thickness and air permeability in Table 6 were further examined.

Table 6 shows that fabric system thickness P-values (0.02 and 0.03) are higher than fabric system air permeability P-values (0.006 and 0.001), inferring that fabric thickness is a less significant property than fabric air permeability in protection from hot water and steam exposures. These findings can be rationalized by the observation that heat transfer is less expedient than mass transfer in hot water and steam exposures.22–24 As the thickness P-values are close to 0.05, and air permeability P-values are significantly less than 0.05, it can be inferred that thickness has a minor/marginal impact on fabric protective performance while air permeability has a strong impact on fabric protective performance. The association between air permeability and second degree burn time under hot water and steam exposures is depicted in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Association between air permeability and second degree burn time under hot water and steam exposures.

According to Figure 9, fabric systems with zero air permeability (B, AF–FAD) show greater second degree burn times than the fabric systems with higher (>0) air permeability (A, AC, AE). An inference test confirmed that the second degree burn time of a fabric system with zero air permeability (an impermeable fabric system) is significantly higher than the second degree burn time of a fabric system with higher air permeability (a permeable fabric system). This observation can be explained by Darcy’s Law which states that the mass transfer through a porous medium (fabric system) is (2)Q=-KA (Pb-Pa )μL where Q = the total discharge of hot water or steam per unit time (m3/s), K = fabric permeability (m2), A = cross sectional area of mass flow, Pa = pressure of the hot water or steam jet, Pb = pressure of the hot water or steam jet after passing through the fabric system, μ = viscosity, and L = fabric thickness. It seems that impermeable fabric systems (B and AF–FAD) do not allow the transfer of hot water or steam through the fabric systems. As a result, the time requirement for a second degree burn increased, enhancing the protective performance of the impermeable fabric systems.

Here, an interesting finding is that, although the B fabric system was impermeable, its second degree burn time was significantly lower than the second degree burn times of the other impermeable fabric systems (AF–FAD) (Figure 9). A possible factor is that the B fabric system is the thinnest of all the impermeable fabric systems, and the B fabric system has a single layer (Table 2). It can be stated that multilayered (double or triple), thick fabric systems (e.g., AF–FAD) provide better protection than non-layered, thin fabric systems (e.g., B). This is quite reasonable because both hot water and steam apply a certain amount of pressure/load which ultimately compresses the fabric system, reducing air volumes inside the fabric systems and lowering the thermal insulation afforded by air. In the compression stage, a multilayered, thick fabric system contains more air than a non-layered, thin fabric system. As a result, the thermal protective performance of a multilayered, thick fabric system is better than that of a non-layered, thin fabric system, especially when heat transfer occurs with hot water and steam exposures. 9,26,27 Contact with hot water or highly pressurized steam might cause thermo-physical properties of the fabric system (surface tension, thermal conductivity, heat capacity) to change, allowing hot water and steam to enter the fabric system more easily and thus increasing the chance of scald burns on the wearer. Multilayered, thick fabric systems can store more hot water than non-layered, thin fabric systems and would be expected to generate body burns more slowly. On entering a fabric system, steam may condense to hot water (Figure 10), and generate scald burns on the wearer.24,31 In a multilayered, thick fabric system this condensation may occur far away from the skin causing less burn injury than in a non-layered, thin fabric system. Figure 10.
Behavior of highly pressurized steam inside a fabric system.

The presence of a thermal liner affects the protective performance of multilayered, thick, impermeable fabric systems. For example, the two outermost layers of the AF (double layered) and the AFC/AFD/AFE (three layered) fabric systems are the same: shell fabric and moisture barrier. However, the AFC/AFD/AFE fabric systems comprise an extra layer of thermal liner in their innermost part (in contact with the wearer’s skin). Due to this added thermal liner, the thermal insulation property of the AFC/AFD/AFE fabric systems is higher than that of the AF fabric system. Consequently, the AFC/AFD/AFE fabric systems resisted heat transfer more effectively than the AF fabric system; that is, the protective performances of the AFC/AFD/AFE fabric systems were higher than the protective performance of the AF fabric system. The thickness of a thermal liner is also important to protective performance. For example, there is a gradual increase in the thickness of the thermal liners in AFC, AFD, and AFE fabric systems. The thickness of AFC, AFD, and AFE fabric systems also gradually increases. As expected, protective performance increases in the order of AFC, AFD, and AFE.

It has also been found that impermeable fabric systems comprising the same number of layers (double layered or three layered) and thickness show significant differences in second degree burn time under hot water and steam exposures (P-value < 0.05) (Figure 9). Although AF and FA fabric systems have the same number of layers and thickness, the protective performance of the FA fabric system is higher than that of the AF fabric system in both hot water and steam exposures (Table 3). Similar observations were made for AFD and FAD fabric systems where, although the fabric systems are of similar thickness, the protective performance of the FAD fabric system is higher than that of the AFD fabric system in both hot water and steam exposures (Table 3). These results are rationalized by considering the difference in position of the moisture barrier in the protective fabric systems. To understand these results, heat and mass transfer is depicted (Figure 11) through two differently configured impermeable fabric systems comprising the same number of layers and the same thickness: System 1 consists of an outer layer comprising a moisture barrier; System 2 consists of an outer layer comprising a shell fabric and the moisture barrier is in its inner layer. Figure 11.
Heat and mass transfer mechanisms through fabric systems in hot water and steam exposures.

Figure 11 shows that in Systems 1 and 2, the incoming hot water or steam is deflected from the moisture barrier. If the moisture barrier is in the outer layer of the fabric system (System 1), much of the heat hazard is deflected long before it reaches the wearer’s skin. If the moisture barrier is in the inner layer of the fabric system (System 2) the hot water or steam is transmitted close to the wearer’s skin. Thus a burn injury is less likely in System 1, which is analogous to fabric systems FA and FAD, than in System 2, which is analogous to fabric systems AF and AFD. It is interesting that the effects of the moisture barrier position are opposite in the cases of hot surface exposure and hot water or steam exposure. This opposite behaviour is likely due to the different thermal energy transfer mechanisms in hot surface exposure versus hot water/steam exposures.

sec.title: Summary and conclusion
sec.p: The present research subjected several protective textile fabric systems to laboratory-simulated flame, radiant-heat, hot surface, and hot water/steam exposures and characterized their protective performances with respect to a skin burn model. The findings demonstrate that the protective performance of fabric systems varies according to the characteristics of the fabric system and the type of thermal exposure.

The amount of thermal insulation and the emissivity or absorbtivity of a fabric system primarily control its protective performance in flame and radiant-heat exposures. It can be concluded that a fabric system surface with a low emissivity enhances protection through a high reflection and low absorption and/or low transmission of thermal energy inside the fabric system. Insulation from flame and radiant-heat exposures was found to be provided by air volumes inside the fabric system that prohibited thermal energy transfer to the sensor (i.e. the wearer). In hot surface contact, hot water splash, and high pressure steam exposures, a certain amount of pressure is imposed on the fabric system; this pressure caused fabric compression which reduced both the contact resistance between the fabric system and the sensor (human skin) and the air volume insulation provided by the fabric system, enhancing heat transfer toward the sensor and reducing the protective performance of the fabric system. Thermo-physical properties (e.g. thermal conductivity, heat capacity) of the fabric systems changed in various thermal exposures. Hence, fabric system may char or pyrolize, reducing their protective performance.

In addition to the heat delivered in hot water and steam exposures, mass transfer through the fabric system may present the primary concern. The study suggests that impermeable fabric systems can reduce mass transfer and enhance the protective performance of the fabric system. Better protection is obtained by stopping or minimizing the mass transfer at the contact point in hot water and steam exposures. Otherwise, a significant amount of hot water and condensed steam might be stored inside the fabric system and might be instantaneously delivered to the human body.

In future, modeling of critical fabric characteristics identified in this study will be employed to optimize the thermal protective performance of the fabric systems. Knowledge gained from modeling experiments will aid the development of clothing that protects against all types of thermal exposure. In another approach, an empirical determination of the variation of thermo-physical properties of fabric systems as a function of thermal exposure type and time will help in the design of fabric systems geared to specific hazards.

sec.title: Authors' Note
sec.p: The findings in this research are based on laboratory tests conducted in simulated and controlled thermal exposures. The conclusions drawn based on these findings do not predict the protective performance of fabric systems in actual field conditions due to the uncontrolled and unqualified nature of real fire hazard scenarios. Conclusions about the safety benefits derived from the results of these experiments should be employed with caution.
